author: ben.affleck
content:
Hey, following up on my thoughts on withdrawal again:
Could we treat withdrawal differently for stakers with `0x00` vs. `0x01` (ETH1 address) withdrawal credentials.
Stakers with `0x00` need a method to set the ETH1 withdrawal address anyway. Since `0x00` stakers were mostly very early adopters, why not verify that the withdrawal transaction comes from the initial deposit address. We could have this for a grace period before the final feature ships. If we limit this possibility to `0x00` withdrawal credentials, I don't see downsides security wise + those stakers were never told anything in regards to how the mechanics of withdrawal works.

author: pietjepuk
content: They were told that the deposit address doesn't matter

author: ben.affleck
content:
Sure, and that is correct. It doesn't matter if you don't want it to matter. If you have your BLS keys for your validator + your keys for your ETH1 address, how can this be less secure then having just your BLS keys for your validator? As I said, this should only be there for a little while and only for stakers with `0x00` credentials. There is no risk for people who no longer have access to their initial ETH1 address. They just wait for the final feature to ship and can set their withdrawal address as they want. I don't get why we should not support early adopters for a very short period that causes no harm to anyone.
To be straight: Nobody was told that `0x01` withdrawal credentials will be introduced in less then 3 month after genesis. If people would have known that, they might have waited for that feature to ship since this protects you from loosing all your funds. Why not be fair to the others?

author: ben.affleck
content:
btw: I wonder how many stakers knew about this. Personally, I have never read anywhere that the initial deposit address doesn't matter and you could throw it away. 
The only thing I knew was that deposit is not possible and that the mechanics is under discussion. 
Was it stated in the specs or in an EIP? Just out of curiosity...

author: ben.affleck
content: To be clear: I have both keys in a secure place, but I feel like I should lobby for people like <@!876973674564030504> since I can fully understand their frustration and their thoughts.

author: _emptymind
content: There could be a wider issue than just people who know their keys are compromised. It's been a long time. There will be a large number of people who may simply be concerned in CASE their keys may have been compromised. The only logical thing to do is to race to withdraw as a PRECAUTION. This worries me because I imagine lot's of people trying to exit destabilising the network or at least flooding it. The problem is exascerbated by concerns about what effect this sudden increase in liquidity might have on price, which in turn could incentivise people to exit ASAP and cause a snowball.

author: _emptymind
content: One thought I had was that maybe we could begin to get people to pre-register who already know they wish to exit. Then we would know the scope of the problem. Another thought I had was to only allow batches of exits in the order in which they first started validating. Still another idea might be to have a window after a withdrawal request is made to see if you get additional conflicting requests. Although this does not itself actually solve the problem, it at least signals that something is wrong with that set of keys and that some kind of compromise must have occurred. And it allows us to know how many are affected. What to do with it is a seperate problem.

author: ben.affleck
content:
+1. 
Wouldn't my suggestion help here too? People with `0x00` credentials could sign a message from their initial deposit address and set any ETH1 address. This would give them confidence that even if their BLS keys are compromised, the worst thing that could happen is slashing. Maybe this causes some validators to exit the race because they know they won't loose everything...

author: _emptymind
content: Withdrawal is definitely my biggest Ethereum worry as a validator. I am slightly nervous about Altair, Prysm code rewrite for V2 and client diversity, quite concerned about the Merge being successful and taking so long, but properly worried about withdrawal and it's overall impact.

author: ben.affleck
content:
Again, +1! Good thoughts. 
I'm kind of surprised that the community is very quite on this. The large increase in ETH price since the launch of phase-0 made some people very nervous. I have the feeling that the amount of solo stakers would be much lower given todays price level and no clear plan for withdrawal.

author: pietjepuk
content: I have, and I have told people as such.

author: pietjepuk
content: It's less secure, because all of a sudden there's an alternative method of withdrawing that wasn't strictly possible before. You're potentially opening up some people to getting their funds drained.

author: ben.affleck
content: It's good to educate people! I was going with a non-custodial staking service and can't remember any note on this. I know, it is a DYOR thing, but I wonder how many were aware of this in the first place.

author: pietjepuk
content: There's also batch deposit contracts that were used, multisigs, or other types of fancy "sources". Not sure what you would do with those then.

author: ben.affleck
content: I'm not in the position to have a strong opinion, but I don't get how this is less secure. It's just for a short period of time and it requires both access to your keys and your eth1 deposit address.

author: pietjepuk
content: "short amount of time" is all an attacker needs, not sure how that makes it better

author: pietjepuk
content: you're still assuming that everyone that deposit has sole ownership of their validator keys and their eth1 withdrawal address no? I'm saying that that's not necessarily the case

author: pietjepuk
content: I might be someone that still has ownership of their BLS withdrawal credentials, but has lost (or never had) sole ownership of the address that made the deposit and the validator keys.

author: _emptymind
content: I was an early adopter and I was validating in time for genesis. I have to say it was not clear to me whether or not the eth1 address I was depositing from would be needed to receive the funds back at withdrawal. I made the (false) assumption that this was why people were trying to deposit from hardware wallets. I don't think there was any narrative on the launchpad or in the somer esat guides - only that withdrawal had simply not been designed yet.

author: ben.affleck
content:
You're right! That's what I assume, and I guess this is what I don't understand. I think this alternative should only be there for a short amount of time (days) before the final feature ships. If you're not the sole owner of your BLS keys after the features ships, then you're lost anyway. If both the eth1 address and your BLS keys are compromised, then what's the point. 
But I got you! I guess I don't have the more sophisticated deposit scenarios in mind.

author: pietjepuk
content: No, my _validator_ keys might be compromised, but the withdrawal keys might not be

author: _emptymind
content: I have a mnemonic which I have safe, and no matter how complicated everything else gets, I cling on to the promise that it will be all I need to exit "somehow", "one day". I think that is the basis for most people to assess whether or not being a validator suits their risk profile.  Hopefully not too many people try to do clever things to protect themselves from loss. Simplicity is the best thing IMO. It is human nature to put things in a "safe place" and forget where it was. This is like that but on a terrifying scale üòÇ

author: ben.affleck
content:
Right, but you will never know that until it is too late. That's why I lobby for a way to set a withdrawal address before the exit + a way to do it from your eth1 deposit address first, before this limitation falls. This way we can keep some people in and not just exit because of precaution, and we support some very early adopters who by mistake got their seed(!) compromised (and know about it).
Thanks for all your thoughts, anyway! I've learned a lot and you have very valid points.

author: pietjepuk
content:
I disagree with "never knowing unless it's too late". You could know, or at least know that there's a high likelihood of those being compromised. E.g. a combination of:
- someone broke in and stole my staking system; I can safely assume my validator keys are compromised. 
- I used a different mnemonic to generate those validator and withdrawal keys than the one of the eth address, and the latter happens to be compromised in the meantime. E.g. I drained it fully by depositing, deemed it no longer necessary to keep it safe, and shared it with the world.

author: pietjepuk
content: I'm not going to argue that it's a _likely_ scenario though. But as long as I played by the rules (keep withdrawal mnemonic safe), I don't see why someone else should all of a sudden get access to my validator balances.

author: ben.affleck
content:
> I used a different mnemonic to generate those validator and withdrawal keys than the one of the eth address, and the latter happens to be compromised in the meantime. E.g. I drained it fully by depositing, deemed it no longer necessary to keep it safe, and shared it with the world.

That's interesting, but I wonder how many generated the keys from two different seeds. AFAIK, most non-custodial services and even the standard deposit cli does this from just one seed.

author: pietjepuk
content: Yes, the withdrawal and validator keys are typically generated from one seed.

author: pietjepuk
content: I mean that _that_ mnemonic is different from the one used for the eth address you deposited from

author: _emptymind
content: I thought it would always be different?

author: _emptymind
content: Are people using the deposit-cli mmemonic to set up a wallet to deposit from?

author: ben.affleck
content: Ah, I see! Yes, sure. But if you lost your mnemonic for the eth1 address only, then still we could debate if you need the validator keys or withdrawal keys to sign a valid message to set the withdrawal address. But I think it dawns on me, and I can imagine a scenario where an attacker gains advantage over you when *you have no more access to the eth1 address*.

author: pietjepuk
content: Well, you can just use an existing mnemonic with the deposit-cli right? So you can just use the one you have on e.g. your Ledger

author: _emptymind
content: ah, didn't realise that was possible

author: ben.affleck
content: yes, that's possible. There is an `existing-mnemonic` switch on the deposit cli

author: pietjepuk
content: Well, you need both keys. The validator keys are responsible for exiting, and the withdrawal keys for the withdrawal. Possibly a single message signed with both

author: pietjepuk
content: I think that if you _only_ have access over your withdrawal credentials (be it eth1 address or BLS keys), you can't exit and withdraw. You need the validator keys as well. Although with BLS keys it's generally easy, because the validator key is a child.

author: ben.affleck
content: Yes, correct! I was just thinking about "staged" scenarios, and if there is a clever order that would support some of the cases without the downsides you mentioned.

author: _emptymind
content: The deposit-cli can generate both with the mnemonic though, right? So compromised mnemonic is game over anyway.

author: pietjepuk
content: If you used the same mnemonic for your eth addresses, and your withdrawal/validator keys, then yes... it's game over if you lose it

author: ben.affleck
content: Sure, if you have the mnenomic, you can re-generate both keys again.

author: ben.affleck
content: btw, the name "withdrawal" key always felt wrong to me since you actually can't withdraw without a prior exit that requires the validator key (AFAIK). Maybe this is a bit misleading...

author: _emptymind
content: So the problem can be defined as proof of custody at some specific point in the past (which could perhaps be a block number).

author: pietjepuk
content: Yes, but at least with BLS keys the validator key is easily derived from the withdrawal key (by default anyway), _even_ if you lose access to the mnemonic

author: _emptymind
content: This is difficult and any solution does not seem like it would be retroactive

author: _emptymind
content: In fact worse, somebody could have keys compromised prior to even attesting. Or even at the point of creation.

author: ben.affleck
content: Is this really correct? I thought that validator and withdrawal keys are childs of the seed and not of each other...

author: pietjepuk
content: If you used the eth2.0-deposit-cli, then indeed the withdrawal key is the parent of the validator key. I doubt anyone went through the effort of saving all private withdrawal keys though (as that's _not_ a default). Just talking hypotheticals here üòâ

author: pietjepuk
content: mnemonic is the parent of _all_ withdrawal and validator keys, and that's the one that people were told to keep safe

author: _emptymind
content: Even if you could prove custody at point of creation it doesn't prove ownership. Although it would seem ill-advised to pass on ownership of a validator to another party, they are not explicitly non-transferable.

author: jgm
content: Just a note on the "flood of exits" concern: when exits are enabled we could be up to 5 exits per epoch, so that's 1,125 exits per day.  If we assume each validator has a balance of around 34ETH at the time of exit we're looking at less than 40,000ETH per day, which I doubt is enough to cause a supply shock, even if it was all sold immediately.

author: _emptymind
content: Even if you can prove who everyone is, it doesn't necessarily reveal who should be allowed to withdraw. I don't think any "rescue" mechanisms will be possible.

author: ben.affleck
content:
Sadly. Of course, my thoughts are very newbieish, but I really wonder if nobody comes up with an idea that is both secure and fair. Maybe there isn't one...
I'm curious how this turns out. Let's see.

author: sky.cactus
content: This isn't how permissionless systems work.  Permissionless means both the good and the bad.  It means that no one can arbitrarily create, destroy, or transfer ETH that isn't theirs, which stops both bad actors and good actors.  There is no one you can convince to make this work, the entire system is designed very explicitly to prevent anyone from being able to do what you want.  It has nothing to do with proving your identify to anyone.

author: _emptymind
content: I am truly sorry for your situation. The point of my comment was to illustrate that no matter how much you can prove who you are and what you did, it doesn't prove ownership. Imagine a situation where you are invited to your host's house for drinks. You spot a painting on the wall and you both get talking and he says "yeah, I bought that for ¬£10K. But if only I could prove its provenance, it would be worth ten times that!" You tell him that you believe you have some information that proves its provenance, so you offer to buy it. You have sunk all your free capital into your validators, so you offer to hand over the keys. Your host considers this for a moment. You have both had a few drinks but he accepts and a verbal contract is made. You hand over the keys and leave with the painting. Next morning you wake up with a headache and an ugly painting. You want out of the deal but your host declines. Now what? You see how easily identity and custody can fail to establish ownership? I agree with others that you should spend your efforts on being first-to-the-post when withdrawals are enabled. I don't think devs are intentionally letting down early adopters, it's just that this issue represents the heart of what a blockchain is. Trustless and immutable.
